questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin finding. You would advise supplementation with which of the following?

choices.text: Vitamin B complex and vitamin K
Safflower oil and vitamin B complex

questions.solution:
The image shows rough, dry skin suggestive of phrynoderma. It is treated by supplementation of safflower oil (rich in essential fatty acids) and vitamin B complex.

Phrynoderma or toad skin is a type of follicular hyperkeratosis. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin E, B, A, C, and essential fatty acids.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest content of thiamine?
questions.solution:
Gingelly (sesame) seeds have the highest content of thiamine.

The thiamine content in various foods in decreasing order are as follows:

  • Gingelly seeds
  • Groundnut
  • Bengal gram
  • Whole wheat
  • Raw rice

Thiamine is lost from rice during the process of milling. As it is a water-soluble vitamin, washing, and cooking rice cause further losses. Hence, it is advisable to avoid highly polished rice and eat parboiled or under-milled rice.

questions.text: A patient presented with loose stools and skin rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Diet history revealed that the patient had been consuming a jowar-rich diet since childhood. This condition results due to excess of which amino acid in the diet?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pellagra. It is caused by the excess of leucine in jowar.

Excess of leucine in jowar (sorghum) and maize interferes with the conversion of tryptophan to niacin causing pellagra.  It presents with the following features:

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis (sun-exposed areas)
  • Dementia

People consuming jowar also have a higher risk of developing genu valgum and osteoporosis due to greater retention of ingested fluoride.

questions.text: What is the recommended daily allowance of vitamin A for a 9-month old baby?
questions.solution:
The RDA of vitamin A for infants is 350 mcg.

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamin A given for a 2-year-old baby with keratomalacia?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The recommended vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child with keratomalacia is 2,00,000 IU given immediately, followed by the same age-specific dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of corneal xerosis among children aged 6 months - 6 years is more than:
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of corneal xerosis among children between 6 months to 6 years (high-risk category) is more than 0.01%.

The presence of any 1 of the following criteria should be considered as evidence of a xerophthalmia problem in the community:

Criteria Prevalence in population at risk (6 months - 6 years)
Night blindness > 1%
Bitot's spots > 0.5%
Corneal xerosis / Corneal ulcer / Keratomalacia > 0.01%
Corneal scar > 0.05%
Serum retinol < 10 mcg/dl >5 %

questions.text: The dose of iodine for lactating women in India according to the recommended dietary allowance is:
questions.solution:
According to the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) 2020 guidelines, the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for dietary iodine in lactating women in India is 280 μg/day.

NIN guidelines on recommended dietary allowance for iodine per day:

Age Male Female
Birth to 6 months 100 mcg 100 mcg
7–12 months 130 mcg 130 mcg
1–9 years 90-120 mcg 90-120 mcg
10–12 years 150 mcg 150 mcg
14–18 years 150 mcg 150 mcg
> 19 years 150 mcg 150 mcg
Pregnancy  — 250 mcg
Lactation  — 280 mcg

Note: According to the WHO guidelines, the RDA during both pregnancy and lactation is 250 mcg.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the epidemiological assessment of iodine deficiency?

choices.text: Median urinary iodine excretion <200 μg/ L indicates insufficient iodine intake
Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive indicator of environmental iodine deficiency
Serum T4 level is a more sensitive indicator of thyroid insufficiency than T3
Quality control of salt is performed by rapid testing with MBI kit

questions.solution:
Median urinary iodine excretion level < 100 μg/L (in non-pregnant population) indicates insufficient iodine intake.

Urinary excretion of iodine is used by the WHO for surveillance and epidemiological studies to classify countries according to the level of iodine deficiency. It is an effective indicator of national programmes against iodine deficiency.

Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive indicator of environmental iodine deficiency. It is also an effective indicator to monitor the impact of a programme. Serum T4 level is a more sensitive indicator of thyroid insufficiency in the population than T3.  

Determination of iodine in salt is a part of the quality control of the product. The UNICEF uses MBI kits to rapidly assess the levels of iodine in salt.

questions.text: What is the recommended dietary allowance of folic acid for a 5-year-old child?
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance of folic acid in a 5-year-old child is 135μg.

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme, what dose of iron and folic acid tablets will you prescribe for a 6-year-old child?

choices.text: 20 mg iron and 100 mcg folic acid
45 mg iron and 400 mcg folic acid
50 mg iron and 350 mcg folic acid
100 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid

questions.solution:
Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme, a 6-year-old child should be given 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid (1 iron and folic acid tablet weekly). The tablet is sugar-coated and pink in color.  

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

1 iron and folic acid tablet starting from the fourth month of pregnancy is continued throughout pregnancy (minimum 180 days). It should also be continued for 180 days post-partum.

60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid,

Sugar-coated and red color

 Daily  Red 

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: How much calcium does a premenopausal woman require on a daily basis?
questions.solution:
A premenopausal woman requires 1000 mg calcium on a daily basis.

questions.text: Individuals with fluoride intake above which of the following are at risk of developing crippling fluorosis?
questions.solution:
Individuals with fluoride intake > 10 mg/L are at risk of developing crippling fluorosis.

Complications of fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake are:

  • Dental fluorosis - 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis - 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis - > 10 mg/L

Genu valgum may occur in people who consume jowar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water bodies. It involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

questions.text: What is the daily recommended intake of water for an elderly woman who is moderately active ?
questions.solution:
A moderately active elderly woman requires 38ml of water/kg/day. 

Water requirement

Male    32-58 ml/kg

Female 27-52 ml/kg
Children  > 60 ml/kg
Adolescent  40-60 ml/kg
Pregnant women  2.1 to 3.2 litres/day
Elderly

Sedentary 33ml/kg 

moderately active 38ml/kg.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits your OPD for a general health check-up. His wife informs that he drinks only 4-5 glasses of water a day. What is the daily adequate intake of water that you would advise him to take according to the WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, for an adult male, the daily adequate intake of water is 3.7 litres.

7 – 12 months   0.8, assumed to be from human milk and complementary foods and beverages

According to Park's textbook, the physiological requirement of water for an adult male is 2 liters per day.

questions.text: What is the normal daily requirement of magnesium in adults?
questions.solution:
The normal daily requirement of magnesium in adults is 400 mg/day

The following are the approximate daily requirements of some electrolytes in adults:

  • Sodium: 1.2 to 1.5 grams (g)/day (up to 2g/day)
  • Potassium: 3500 mg/day
  • Calcium: 1000-1200 mg/day
  • Magnesium: 400 mg/day
